title: 111_s591
content:
The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission for the purposes of addressing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel. The commission's composition, duties, powers, staff, compensation, security clearances, reports, and termination are outlined in the Act. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel, known as the "Commission," is established to evaluate improvements in the US approach to waste management if the Yucca Mountain repository is not operational. The Commission will submit a report to Congress with findings and recommendations for managing defense waste, spent nuclear fuel, high-level waste, and commercial radioactive waste. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with relevant committees. Qualifications for appointees include not being nongovernmental. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by leaders in consultation with relevant committees. Appointees must not be engaged in certain activities or hold specific government positions. They should be prominent US citizens with expertise in various fields. The Commission, comprised of 9 members appointed within 90 days of the Act, focuses on science related to nuclear fuel management, energy, governmental service, environmental policy, law, public administration, or foreign affairs. The Chairperson, appointed under subsection (a)(5), leads the Commission, which meets as needed with a quorum of five members. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation, providing funding for storage and management, exploring cost-sharing options with private industry, and establishing centralized interim storage facilities. The curr_chunk discusses the development of nuclear fuel management technology, establishing centralized interim storage facilities, research on advanced fuel cycle technologies, transferring spent nuclear fuel inventories to the Department of Energy, and requiring the transfer of spent nuclear fuel inventories while long-term solutions are developed. The curr_chunk discusses future nuclear fuel inventories at reactor sites, the transfer of spent nuclear fuel inventories to at-reactor dry casks for public safety, permanent deep geologic disposal for civilian and defense wastes, and additional management and technological approaches determined by the Commission. The Commission will consult with various stakeholders, submit recommendations on fee disposition, and analyze financial impacts for a final report to Congress. The Commission will submit a final report to Congress on the contractual liability of the Federal Government under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and administer oaths. It can also enter into contracts and obtain information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out its duties under this Act. The Commission can request information from various government entities and must handle it in accordance with the law. Federal agencies, including the General Services Administration, can provide administrative support to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission can request assistance from other government departments and agencies for services, funds, facilities, staff, and support services as authorized by law. Additionally, the Commission can use the United States mails like other federal agencies. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission, and the Commission can have staff. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain federal employment rules. The staff director and personnel are considered federal employees for specific purposes under the United States Code. The Commission's personnel are federal employees for specific purposes under the United States Code. Members of the Commission are not considered employees. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their rights. The Commission can procure consultant services at specified rates. SEC. 9. Compensation for Commission members may not exceed the daily rate of pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. Travel expenses are provided for Commission members while on duty. SEC. 10. Commission members are eligible for security clearances. SEC. 10. Security clearances are provided to Commission members and staff by Federal agencies to access classified information, following existing procedures and requirements. SEC. 11. REPORTS.

An interim report must be made public for comment within 1 year of the Act's enactment, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations agreed upon by a majority of Commission members. A final report must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Commission's first meeting, including agreed-upon items, dissenting opinions with explanations, and consideration of public comments. 

SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Sums necessary to implement the Act are authorized to be appropriated, remaining available until expended.

SEC. 13. TERMINATION. SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Authorized appropriations for the Act remain available until expended.

SEC. 13. TERMINATION.

Commission authority ends 180 days after final report submission. During this period, the Commission can conclude activities, testify to Congress, and disseminate the final report.
